resources.string: Welcome to Kali Linux NetHunter by Offensive Security! This application is designed to make it easier to execute attacks and control services. The navigation menu contains links to useful commands, settings, macros, and attack configuration pages. Most configurations work out of the box but some may require some minimal tweaking.
Various Kali network services can be started and stopped via the buttons in this part of the interface.
The Powersploit payload provides you a choice of reverse meterpreter HTTP/S payloads. "URL to payload" should be a URL accessible to the victim machine where the larger payload is downloaded to.
This Windows CMD payload allows you to enter raw commands to a Windows command prompt. Hitting the list menu will allow you to choose keyboard layout or UAC bypass options.

This is our implementation of the BadUSB attack as demonstrated at Black Hat USA 2014. Enabling this USB mode will turn your device with its OTG USB cable into a network interface when plugged into a target computer. Connecting the USB cable to a PC will force all traffic from that PC (Windows or Linux) through the NetHunter device, where the traffic can be MITM\'ed.
This is the configuration page for MANA, an evil access point implementation by Sensepost. The various MITM logs get written to the /var/lib/mana-toolkit directory in the Kali chroot..
The hostapd configuration file used by Mana.
The dhcpd configuration file used by Mana.
The dnsspoof configuration file used by Mana.
The Mana script that does full NAT & SSL interception.
The Mana script that does full NAT only.
The Mana script that does full NAT & BDFProxy HTTP routing to port 8080.
The Mana no-upstream EAP run script.
Dnsmasq is a lightweight DNS forwarder and DHCP server that can easily be configured to provide DNS and DHCP services to a small network.
hostapd is a user space daemon for wireless access point and authentication servers. You can use hostapd to easily create a wireless access point using these configuration options:

The DuckHunter script can easily convert "USB Rubber Ducky" scripts into NetHunter HID format. You can generate preconfigured scripts at the incredibly useful Ducky Toolkit site, or check out the Rubber Ducky script syntax from the official README
Easily set up NAT or use iptables rules to route traffic.
Error launching intent. Install Android Terminal!

Change the MAC of any network interface.

It can be randomly generated or manually typed. 

The MAC must contain 6 pair of combinations using the charset: [0â€“9|A-F|a-f] something like:

 00:11:22:ab:cd:ef

This will reset the wlan0 MAC to his original state.

After the reset the phone will be rebooted.

 This is useful if the wifi is stuck with a incompatible MAC address.
The wlan0 interface does not support every combination of MAC addresses, so this feature is disabled for wlan0.\n\nIf your wifi gets stuck, reset the MAC with the menu option.
Uh oh! Nethunter can\'t find busybox!

string-array.name: interface_opts
string-array.item: usb0 (USB > Ethernet for the Nexus7 2013 when tethering | badusb)

resources.string: Warning: Uninstalling the Nethunter app without FIRST removing the chroot will result in an incomplete removal of the app.
An existing Kali chroot directory was found!
No Kali chroot directory was found.

There\'s no going back. You lose everything in your chroot. Forever-ever.\n\nNOTE: To fully ensure the chroot is not mounted and no processes are using it, THE DEVICE WILL NOW BE REBOOTED, then the chroot will be deleted.
The device is being restarted. (No complaining. You were just told this would happen!)
The file looks good, so no need to re-download it.
Deleting to make room for download…
Problem deleting old file. Just sayin\'.
Nowhere to write to. Make sure you have your external storage mounted and available.
Download failed. Check your network connection and external storage and try again.
The chroot is being extracted. This could take a bit. If it goes more than 15 minutes, please panic.
Kali chroot is mounted and NOT deleted. Reboot again to remove!!
Kali chroot is mounted and NOT yet migrated. Reboot again to try again!!
The chroot is being downloaded. This could take a while…
Something went wrong verifying the downloaded file. Whoops. Try again.

The \"chroot\" is a full installation of Kali Linux that shares processing, networking, storage, and other resources with Android. It resides in your internal app storage area and requires about 400MB for the minimal core installation.

Nethunter installs and uses a standard Kali Linux distribution \"under the hood\". To support this functionality, some standard Android security features such as Security Enhanced Linux (selinux) are disabled. Moreover, Kali\'s Linux processes may run with full root privileges and can therefore access system functionality well beyond the normal Android security model. Consider therefore that this device, as a hybrid, may not be as secure as either standard Kali Linux OR standard Android, and you are advised not to install or use Nethunter on \"daily driver\" devices or devices which store or access sensitive/private data.
Nethunter is licensed under the GPLv2 and source is available at github.com/offensive-security. Some icons are licensed from Google, Inc. under CC BY 4.0.

Choose some "metapackages". The chroot will also be upgraded (via "apt-get update/dist-upgrade").

Selecting metapackages you already have installed (or no packages at all) simply update/upgrades without removing anything.

Depending on what metapackages you select, you may be asked to do stuff (such as set passwords for services), so pay attention.
Local storage requirements may be in the 20+ GB range. This installation/update will be performed in a terminal, so watch for issues. When completed, press the back button.

Whoopsy daisy! Nethunter requires elevated administrator (root) privileges.

Make sure root access is available. Depending on your version of Android, this may require a "rooting" procedure to install the su binary.

On CyanogenMod or CM-based Android, you may need to go to your device Settings, and under Developer Options, enable Root access for Apps.

Additionally, you will need to make sure busybox is installed, usually to /system/xbin/busybox.

You appear to already have an existing Kali chroot from an older version of Nethunter.

Migrating it to its new location requires a reboot.

Or, you can leave the old chroot alone and install a new chroot. If you choose this option, make sure you have enough storage for both.
